dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Ugh! I just— I read this article, and it's like, you think things are bad, but then you read this, and it's even worse! Right? Like, you think you know, but then you see, what was it, the top 1% now control over 70% of the world's wealth? Just insane!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ugh! I just- I read this article, and it's like, you think things are bad, but then you read this, and it's even worse! Right? Like, you think you know, but then you see, what was it, the top one percent now control over seventy percent of the world's wealth? Just insane!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Yes, exactly! I mean, I almost threw my coffee when I read that. And that's after we supposedly started paying closer attention to inequality.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes, exactly! I mean, I almost threw my coffee when I read that. And that's after we supposedly started paying closer attention to inequality.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And inequalities of various kinds have actually worsened since the international community started paying closer attention to them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, like, what are we even doing? Exactly! And the whole global economy, it's so weak, so vulnerable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, like, what are we even doing? Exactly! And the whole global economy, it's so weak, so vulnerable.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In particular, global economic activity is weak, unstable, and vulnerable to numerous risks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Especially, like, with private equity just taking over everything. Oh my gosh, yes! That part! And the recovery, it’s not creating good quality employment, just more insecurity!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Especially, like, with private equity just taking over everything. Oh my gosh, yes! That part! And the recovery, it's not creating good quality employment, just more insecurity!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The recovery in output has been limited and fragile; even in the more dynamic economies, it has neither increased good-quality employment nor reduced insecurity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah! It's like, the system itself is designed to make it worse, isn't it? It's not just national policies, it’s the international ones too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah! It's like, the system itself is designed to make it worse, isn't it? It's not just national policies, it's the international ones too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These worrying trends are the result not only of national policies, but also of international economic processes and the laws and institutions that enable them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Totally! Like, the economic architecture, these associated patterns of trade and capital flows—they just drive inequality. New assets, intellectual property, data analytics...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally! Like, the economic architecture, these associated patterns of trade and capital flows-they just drive inequality. New assets, intellectual property, data analytics...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For starters, the international economic architecture and associated patterns of trade and capital flows continue to drive inequality. ... These include the creation of new assets in the form of intellectual property rights, the emergence of new products like data analytics...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: And the privatization, right? Of like, public services and even nature? Which only helps, uh, like a select few!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the privatization, right? Of like, public services and even nature? Which only helps, uh, like a select few!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the privatization of public or social assets such as nature, and the private delivery of public services.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Yes! And then all that market concentration, the rent-seeking by large companies. It just intensifies everything!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yes! And then all that market concentration, the rent-seeking by large companies. It just intensifies everything!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These changes have increased levels of market concentration and monopoly control, and encouraged additional rent-seeking by large companies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: And then, then we get to taxes! Or, like, the lack of them from the rich and the multinational companies! Five trillion dollars lost annually!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then, then we get to taxes! Or, like, the lack of them from the rich and the multinational companies! Five trillion dollars lost annually!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Uh huh! Five trillion! Which means governments can’t fund, you know, SDG-related measures, or, like, anything else citizens need!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh huh! Five trillion! Which means governments can't fund, you know, S D G-related measures, or, like, anything else citizens need!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Corporate tax avoidance denies governments the resources they need to finance SDG-related measures and meet citizens other pressing concerns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: And the fiscal austerity! Don't even get me started on that!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the fiscal austerity! Don't even get me started on that!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, but we have to! It's choking off green public investments, it's cutting social programs, forcing women to pick up the slack with unpaid labor.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, but we have to! It's choking off green public investments, it's cutting social programs, forcing women to pick up the slack with unpaid labor.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is also choking off the green public investments required to decarbonize economies... Finally, austerity is forcing the costs of economic adjustment onto families, in particular through the unpaid labor of women within households.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: It's just, it's so backwards! But there's, like, no economic justification for it! Portugal grew out of debt, like, without austerity. China, Vietnam, they did things differently and thrived!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just, it's so backwards! But there's, like, no economic justification for it! Portugal grew out of debt, like, without austerity. China, Vietnam, they did things differently and thrived!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, there is little economic justification for such austerity. Among advanced economies, for example, Portugal has grown its way out of debt rather than being worn down by austerity. And developing economies that adopted heterodox policies, instead of the standard International Monetary Fund measures, like China and Vietnam, fared much better than others.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: So why is the IMF still pushing these, uh, orthodox policies that just increase poverty in developing nations?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So why is the I M F still pushing these, uh, orthodox policies that just increase poverty in developing nations?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet the IMF, abetted by other international institutions, continues to push orthodox policies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 1
dialogue_turns.text: It's infuriating! Right? So if leaders at the UN this month don't actually get serious about these fundamental challenges, I mean, don't be surprised when people just, like, tune out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's infuriating! Right? So if leaders at the U N this month don't actually get serious about these fundamental challenges, I mean, don't be surprised when people just, like, tune out.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: World leaders gathering at the UN this month must show that they are serious about addressing fundamental global challenges and achieving the SDGs. Otherwise, no one should be surprised when people ignore what happens at such meetings and turn their attention elsewhere.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Speaker 2
dialogue_turns.text: Seriously. I know! They have to do something!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Seriously. I know! They have to do something!
